alt_statements.statement: At my age, I’ve seen how words can either stitch a community together or tear it apart, and I don’t think the First Amendment should be a shield for targeted hatred that incites violence or dehumanizes whole groups. We should protect robust, even uncomfortable debate, but when speech is used to threaten, harass, or systematically intimidate people based on who they are, that crosses a line and deserves legal limits. As someone who spent a career in social work, I’ve watched hate speech ripple out into real harm, especially for vulnerable folks, and I believe a decent society has a responsibility to draw boundaries that protect people’s dignity and safety.

I believe free speech is a core American value and should be strongly protected, even when the speech is offensive or hateful, because once the government starts deciding which opinions are allowed, everyone’s rights are at risk. That said, there should be clear limits when speech directly incites violence, makes true threats, or targets individuals for harassment, because that crosses the line from expressing an opinion into harming others and undermining public safety and order.

As someone who works every day with people from all kinds of backgrounds and sees how fragile both bodies and communities can be, I think free speech should be strongly protected, but not when it directly incites violence or intentionally targets and dehumanizes specific groups. Hate speech that clearly creates a hostile, unsafe environment—especially in public institutions like schools, workplaces, or healthcare settings—goes beyond “just words” and starts to undermine others’ basic freedoms and safety. We can and should tolerate offensive or unpopular opinions, but when speech is used as a tool to systematically intimidate or exclude, I believe it’s reasonable for the law and institutions to draw a line.

Como cristiana y alguien que vino de Cuba buscando más libertad, valoro mucho la libertad de expresión, porque sé lo que es vivir donde uno no puede decir lo que piensa. Pero también creo que cuando las palabras se convierten en amenazas claras, llamados a la violencia o humillan directamente la dignidad de una persona por su raza, religión o país de origen, ahí sí debe haber límites. No se trata de prohibir opiniones diferentes o duras, sino de impedir que el odio se use para hacer daño real a otros hijos de Dios.

As someone who works closely with people from all walks of life, I’ve seen how words can either help heal or deeply harm. I believe free speech is essential and should be strongly protected, but there should be limits when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or credible threats against specific groups. Hate speech that crosses into targeted intimidation or endangers people’s safety shouldn’t be tolerated, especially in a society that claims to value dignity and equal treatment. We can protect open dialogue without giving cover to speech that’s clearly meant to terrorize or dehumanize others.

I think free speech is one of the core things that makes this country what it is, and we should be very careful about letting the government decide what people are allowed to say, even if it’s ugly or hateful. That said, once speech clearly crosses into direct threats, targeted harassment, or actively inciting violence, there should be legal limits and consequences. I’d rather see most hateful views countered through social pressure, education, and open debate than through broad censorship laws that could easily get misused down the road.

As someone who works in insurance, I see how rules and guardrails are necessary to prevent real harm, not just to protect institutions but individual people. I think free speech should be strongly protected, but there should be legal limits when it directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against protected groups, because that crosses from expression into endangering others’ safety and dignity. We already accept that you can’t yell “fire” in a crowded theater for public safety; targeted hate speech that predictably leads to threats or attacks should be treated similarly.

As someone who cares a lot about community and justice, I think free speech is crucial, but it shouldn’t be used as a shield for speech that directly dehumanizes people or incites violence against them. Hate speech that targets people for their race, religion, gender, or identity and creates a real risk of harm or harassment should face legal and social consequences. At the same time, we should be careful that laws don’t become so broad that they silence uncomfortable but necessary conversations about inequality and power.

As someone who came to this country from Korea and has found a home in both my church and my local community, I believe free speech is fundamental—but not limitless. When speech intentionally dehumanizes or incites violence against people because of their race, religion, or identity, it stops being “just an opinion” and becomes a tool of harm that government and institutions have a responsibility to restrict. I’ve seen how easily hateful language can create fear and silence vulnerable people, so I support strong legal and social limits on incitement and targeted harassment while still protecting room for honest debate and even uncomfortable disagreement.

As someone who deeply values the Constitution and free speech, I’m very wary of the government deciding what people are allowed to say, even when it’s hateful or offensive. I think the line should be drawn where speech directly incites violence, credible threats, or targeted harassment, especially toward children or vulnerable people. Beyond that, the answer to bad or hateful ideas should be more speech, stronger communities, and better education—not censorship.

I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, but they shouldn’t be allowed to say things that clearly try to hurt or scare other people because of who they are. My parents and my church teach me that everyone is made in God’s image, so words that encourage hate or violence against a group should be stopped, especially to keep kids and vulnerable people safe.

La libertad de expresión es un valor fundamental, y en este país me dieron ese derecho que en Cuba no existía, así que soy muy cuidadoso antes de pedir límites. Sin embargo, cuando las palabras se convierten en llamados directos a la violencia o en acoso sistemático contra una persona o grupo, el Estado debe intervenir, porque eso ya no es opinión, es amenaza. No me gusta la censura por ofensas o ideas impopulares, pero sí creo que debe haber una línea clara donde termina la crítica, por dura que sea, y empieza el peligro real para la seguridad y dignidad básica de las personas.

I think people should be allowed to say what they think, but they shouldn’t be allowed to say mean things that hurt others just because of their race, religion, or who they are. My parents and church teach me that everyone is a child of God and deserves respect, so if speech makes people feel scared or unsafe, I think there should be rules to stop it.

I think free speech is really important, but hate speech that directly targets people for things like their race, religion, or where they’re from should have limits, especially if it encourages violence or bullying. As someone who’s Catholic and likes learning about different cultures, it bothers me when words are used to make people feel unsafe or less human. People should still be able to disagree and debate ideas, but not use that as an excuse to attack others or make school or public places feel hostile.

I think people should be allowed to say almost anything, even if it’s ugly or offensive, because once you start letting the government decide what words are off limits, it’s too easy for that power to be abused. That said, I draw the line at direct threats, calls for violence, or deliberate, targeted harassment meant to seriously harm or terrorize someone. As a Catholic, I try to respect the dignity of others, but I’d rather combat hateful speech with more speech and better ideas than with laws that could eventually be used to shut people like me up too.

I was raised to believe the First Amendment is one of the bedrocks of this country, so I’m wary of the government deciding which opinions are allowed, even when those opinions are ugly. That said, when speech crosses the line into direct threats, harassment, or clearly inciting violence against a group, I think it stops being “free speech” and becomes a public safety issue where limits and consequences are appropriate.

Coming from a liberal background and working in education, I think free speech is crucial, but I don’t believe it should protect direct hate speech that targets and dehumanizes specific groups, especially in ways that can incite harassment or violence. In my view, we should draw the line where speech stops being about expressing an opinion and starts actively creating a hostile environment that makes others unsafe or unable to participate fully in public or campus life.

As someone who came to this country from Cambodia and became a U.S. citizen, I value free speech deeply because I know what it’s like to live where people are afraid to speak their minds. At the same time, my faith and my experience as a minority teach me that words can be used to dehumanize and incite real harm. I think hate speech should be protected up to the point where it directly threatens, harasses, or clearly incites violence against individuals or groups—at that line, the government has a duty to step in. Outside of that, families, churches, and communities should be the ones to challenge hateful ideas and promote respect, not the government policing every offensive word.

I think people should be able to speak their minds, even if I don’t agree with them, but there’s a line when words turn into real harm. When speech directly threatens, harasses, or clearly encourages violence against a group, that’s where limits make sense, because everyone deserves to feel safe in their own community. I’m raising my kids to respect others and nature, and I don’t see how letting hate fester out in the open with no boundaries helps anyone grow or live peacefully.

I believe free speech is a bedrock American value, and even ugly or hateful words are better answered with more speech, not government bans. That said, when words turn into direct threats, calls to violence, or targeted harassment that puts people in real danger, the law ought to step in. From what I’ve seen in my long life, once you let the government decide which opinions are “too hateful” to say, it’s a short step to silencing folks just for being unpopular or politically out of step.

I believe free speech is one of our most important rights, and we should be very careful about letting the government decide what people can and can’t say, even when it’s ugly. That said, when speech directly threatens or incites violence against a group of people, or clearly creates a dangerous environment—like encouraging harassment or attacks—I think that crosses a line where the law and community standards should step in.

I think people should be allowed to share their thoughts, but they shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean things that hurt or scare others just because of who they are. At my school, we’re taught to be kind and include everyone, so I feel like hate speech should be stopped, especially if it makes someone feel unsafe or like they don’t belong.

As someone who values both civil liberties and the dignity of vulnerable communities, I believe free speech should be strongly protected, but not absolute. Speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or clear, targeted discrimination against specific groups crosses a line where the state has a responsibility to intervene. We’ve seen in history and in financial markets alike how unchecked, dehumanizing rhetoric can normalize harmful behavior and destabilize communities. Reasonable limits on hate speech, carefully defined and applied, help ensure that “freedom” isn’t weaponized to silence or endanger others.

As someone who works every day with children and adolescents, I’ve seen how words can deeply wound and create a hostile environment, so I do believe there should be limits on speech that deliberately targets people based on race, religion, gender, or other identities with the intent to harass or incite violence. At the same time, I value open dialogue and believe that unpopular or uncomfortable opinions should still be allowed, as long as they don’t cross the line into threats, targeted abuse, or creating an unsafe learning or community environment.

As a Black man and a liberal Protestant, I believe free speech is vital, but I’ve seen firsthand how unchecked hate speech can escalate into real harm for people who look like me and the students I help protect. I think the line should be drawn where speech directly incites violence, targets individuals or groups with threats, or creates a hostile environment that strips others of their ability to safely participate in public life—especially on campus. Laws and university policies should protect open debate while clearly restricting speech that dehumanizes or endangers marginalized communities.

As a nurse and a mom, I see every day how words can either heal or seriously harm, and I don’t think “free speech” should be a shield for speech that directly dehumanizes or incites violence against others. We need strong protections for open debate, criticism, and even uncomfortable opinions, but when hate speech crosses into threats, harassment, or targeting people for who they are, there should be legal and institutional consequences. Protecting vulnerable communities and maintaining a safe, respectful environment—at work, at school, and online—isn’t a contradiction to free speech, it’s what allows everyone to participate in it.

As someone who cares about both individual freedom and creating a safe, inclusive community—especially for my kids—I think free speech should be strongly protected, but not when it directly incites violence, harassment, or clearly targets people in ways that endanger their safety. Hate speech that crosses into threats, stalking, or creates a hostile environment where certain groups are effectively silenced shouldn’t be shielded by the First Amendment. We can and should argue, disagree, and challenge each other’s ideas, but we don’t need to protect speech whose main purpose is to dehumanize and intimidate.

As someone who has experienced anti-Asian bias and is raising children in a country that is not my birthplace, I believe free speech should be strongly protected, but not when it directly incites violence, harassment, or creates an environment where certain groups are systematically terrorized. Hate speech that targets people based on race, religion, nationality, or other inherent traits should face legal limits when it crosses into threats, organized intimidation, or clear incitement, because that’s no longer just “expression” but an attack on others’ basic safety and dignity.

As a cop and a dad, I think people should be able to say unpopular, even ugly, things—but the line gets drawn when speech directly threatens, harasses, or incites violence against others. I see firsthand how hateful rhetoric can escalate into real harm, especially for vulnerable communities, so I support legal limits on speech that targets and endangers people based on race, religion, gender, or similar traits. Free speech is crucial in a democracy, but it shouldn’t be a shield for terrorizing others or creating a climate where violence feels justified.

My mom and dad say we should never use mean words that hurt people because of how they look or who they are, and I’m learning to be kind to everyone. I think if words make people scared or hurt on purpose, grown-ups should stop that, just like they stop hitting or pushing on the playground.

Coming from an immigrant Mexican family and seeing how words can be used to dehumanize people like me or my comunidad, I think free speech should be strongly protected, but not when it crosses into direct threats, harassment, or calls for violence. Hate speech that clearly targets people for who they are and puts them in danger shouldn’t be treated like just another opinion; there should be legal and social consequences. At the same time, we have to be careful not to use “hate speech” as an excuse to shut down uncomfortable but honest debates about race, immigration, or politics.

As someone who cherishes both the Constitution and my Catholic faith, I believe free speech is a core American right that must be protected, even when the words are ugly or offensive. That said, when speech crosses the line into direct threats, incitement to violence, or targeted harassment that clearly endangers others, the law should step in. We should challenge hateful ideas through open debate, good example, and strong communities, not by broadly criminalizing offensive opinions.

Free speech is a core American value, and as someone who’s spent a life building a business and valuing individual responsibility, I’m very wary of giving government too much power to decide what people can and can’t say—even if the speech is ugly or hateful. That said, speech that directly incites violence, makes true threats, or is used to coordinate criminal acts should absolutely be restricted and punished. The right answer isn’t policing every offensive word, but enforcing existing laws against violence and harassment while using education, strong community standards, and personal accountability to push back against hate.

I think free speech is super important, but hate speech that directly targets people for who they are and makes them feel unsafe shouldn’t be protected. Once words start encouraging violence, bullying, or discrimination against groups, that crosses a line, because everyone deserves to feel safe and equal in their community.

As someone who’s spent a lot of time teaching young people and now volunteers in a community garden, I’ve seen how words can either build a community or poison it. I think free speech is crucial in a healthy democracy, but when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or systematic discrimination against a group, society has a responsibility to draw a firm line. We don’t let people dump toxic waste into a river just because it’s “their property,” and likewise we shouldn’t let speech that clearly endangers others flow unchecked into our shared public space. Limits should be narrow and carefully defined, but they should exist where speech stops being expression of an idea and becomes a weapon against people’s basic safety and dignity.

Free speech is a cornerstone of our democracy, and even ugly or offensive opinions should generally be protected, because once the government starts deciding which ideas can’t be spoken, everyone’s rights are at risk. That said, there must be firm limits when speech directly incites violence, makes credible threats, or is used to harass and terrorize individuals or groups in a way that endangers their safety or basic freedoms.

My mamá and papá tell me that Jesús wants us to use our words to be kind, not to hurt people, so I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean things that make others feel scared or unwanted. It’s okay to disagree and talk about hard things, but if words are used to bully or hate someone because of who they are, there should be rules to stop that and help everyone feel safe, like when teachers stop kids from being mean on the playground.

As someone who grew up in the South and remembers what open racism looked and felt like, I believe the First Amendment is vital, but it doesn’t give anyone the right to threaten or incite violence against others. People should be free to speak their minds, even if it offends, but once speech turns into direct intimidation, harassment, or clear calls for harm, the law ought to step in. My faith teaches me that words can either build up or tear down, so we should defend free speech while setting firm limits where it endangers people’s safety and dignity.

Free speech is a core American value, and I’m very wary of the government deciding which speech is allowed and which isn’t, even when it’s ugly or hateful. That said, when speech directly incites violence, targeted harassment, or credible threats against specific people or groups, it crosses a line and should be restricted and punished. As a Catholic and a former teacher, I believe the better answer to hate is strong counter-speech, education, and community standards—not broad censorship that can easily be abused.

Free speech is vital, but I don’t think it should be a shield for speech that actively dehumanizes people or incites violence against them. As someone who works with students and cares deeply about creating safe, nurturing environments—much like I want for my own kids—I believe hate speech that crosses into targeted harassment, credible threats, or clear incitement should be restricted. We can protect open debate and even deeply unpopular opinions while still drawing a firm line where words are used as weapons to intimidate and marginalize vulnerable groups.

As someone who’s seen how words can turn into real discrimination, I think there have to be some limits on hate speech, especially when it targets people for things like race, religion, or disability and creates a threatening or hostile environment. Free speech is important in a democracy, but once it crosses into inciting violence, harassment, or stripping others of their dignity and safety, the law and our communities should step in.

Free speech has to stay as close to absolute as possible, even when it comes to hate speech, because once the government starts deciding which opinions are too offensive, nobody’s safe—especially people with minority beliefs like mine. That said, speech that directly incites violence or makes credible threats crosses a clear line and should be punished, not because it’s offensive, but because it’s an act of aggression.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean things that hurt others just because of their skin color, where they’re from, or what they believe. My parents and church teach me that God wants us to love our neighbors, so words that make people feel scared or hated shouldn’t be okay. We can still say what we think, but not in a way that tries to hurt or bully whole groups of people.

I think people should usually be allowed to say what they believe, even if others don’t agree, because that’s part of being free. But I also believe there should be limits when speech turns into serious hate against a group of people, especially if it encourages hurting them or bullying them. That kind of speech can make people feel unsafe and go against what I learn at church about treating others with kindness.

As someone who thinks a lot about systems and evidence, I see free speech as a core democratic value, but not an absolute one—especially when it comes to hate speech that dehumanizes people and predictably fuels real-world harm. Given this country’s history with racism and the way targeted rhetoric can legitimize discrimination and violence, I believe the line should be drawn at direct incitement, harassment, and sustained, identity-based abuse in public and institutional spaces. We shouldn’t criminalize mere offensive ideas, but we should regulate and sanction speech that systematically undermines the safety and equal standing of protected groups, particularly where there’s a clear power imbalance.

I believe free speech is a core American value and important to protect, even when we strongly disagree, but I also think there need to be limits when speech directly threatens, harasses, or incites violence against others. As someone who works closely with families and kids and tries to model kindness and respect, I don’t think we should tolerate speech that’s intended to terrorize or dehumanize people in public spaces. Laws should be careful and narrow so we don’t slide into policing every offensive opinion, but communities, schools, workplaces, and online platforms should have clear rules against hate speech that targets people based on who they are.

As someone who believes deeply in both American freedoms and Catholic values of human dignity, I think free speech should be broad, but not absolute when it comes to hate speech. We shouldn’t criminalize every offensive opinion, but speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or clear discrimination against a protected group crosses a line and should face legal consequences. In my community work and as a mom, I see how words can create an environment where people feel unsafe or dehumanized, and I don’t think protecting that kind of speech is worth the social damage it causes.

As someone who has spent a lifetime in classrooms and community spaces, I believe words can either build people up or tear them down. I support free speech, but I think when speech crosses into direct threats, harassment, or deliberate incitement of violence against a group, it should be limited, because that kind of “speech” undermines the safety and dignity that a healthy community requires. We should encourage open dialogue, even on uncomfortable topics, but not allow hate to masquerade as “just an opinion” when it clearly harms others and poisons our public life.

As someone who believes deeply in healing and minimizing harm, I don’t think truly free societies can allow hate speech that directly dehumanizes or incites violence against others. We all benefit from robust, even uncomfortable, discussion—but when speech becomes a weapon that traumatizes, marginalizes, or endangers vulnerable groups, it stops being “expression” and starts being abuse. I support legal limits on speech that explicitly threatens or advocates violence, and strong social accountability for rhetoric that stigmatizes people for who they are. True freedom of speech should coexist with an ethical responsibility to protect the dignity and safety of every person.

I think people should usually be allowed to say what they think, even if others don’t like it, because free speech is important for learning and discussing ideas. But hate speech that directly attacks or threatens groups of people, like saying they should be hurt or don’t deserve rights, should not be allowed, because it can lead to violence and makes it unsafe for kids and families.

I believe people should have broad freedom to express their opinions, even unpopular ones, but once speech targets a group with threats, dehumanizing language, or clear intent to incite violence, it stops being “just speech” and becomes harm. In a community, words shape how we treat each other, and hate speech can create fear and shut people out of public life. I support reasonable legal limits on explicit incitement and harassment, along with strong social consequences—education, public condemnation, and community standards—to push back against hateful rhetoric.

As someone who values both civil liberties and the real-world impact of words on people’s health and safety, I think free speech should be strongly protected, but not absolute. When “hate speech” directly incites violence, clearly targets and harasses specific individuals or groups, or creates a credible threat that they will be harmed or driven from public life, it crosses a line and should face legal limits. At the same time, offensive or bigoted opinions that don’t rise to that level should generally remain legal, and we should counter them through education, dialogue, and social accountability rather than censorship.

Free speech is a bedrock American value, and as someone who swore an oath to uphold the Constitution, I believe even offensive views generally need to be protected so government doesn’t become the arbiter of acceptable opinion. That said, there’s a clear line where hate speech turns into direct threats, incitement to violence, or targeted harassment that creates a real risk to people’s safety and public order—and that’s where the law should step in. In my view, we should punish criminal actions, not ideas, but we shouldn’t hesitate to act when speech is being used as a weapon to intimidate or endanger others.

As someone who believes deeply in both free expression and community responsibility, I think there should be limits on speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against protected groups. Hate speech that creates a climate of fear or real harm—especially for kids and families in our community—crosses a line from opinion into abuse and should be restricted. At the same time, we should be cautious not to silence uncomfortable but peaceful debate, because open dialogue is essential for social progress and understanding across cultures.

My mommy and daddy say we should never say mean things that hurt people’s feelings, especially about how they look or where they’re from, because Jesus wants us to be kind and love everyone. I think people should be allowed to talk, but if someone is using words to make others feel scared or bad for who they are, then the grown‑ups should stop it.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean things that hurt others just because of their race, religion, or who they are, because that can make kids feel unsafe at school and in the community. It’s okay to share opinions and even disagree, but when words become hate speech that bullies or makes groups feel scared, there should be rules and consequences so everyone can feel respected and protected.

I think free speech is important, but hate speech that targets people for their race, gender, or other parts of who they are should have limits when it leads to threats, harassment, or real harm. As a Black girl, I know words can make people feel unsafe at school or in public, and that can shut down their ability to speak and be themselves. We should still allow people to express unpopular opinions, but once speech encourages violence, bullying, or discrimination, there should be consequences.

At my age, I’ve seen how words can either knit a community together or tear it apart, and hate speech almost always does the latter. I believe people should be free to speak their minds, but when speech deliberately dehumanizes others or incites violence—especially against vulnerable groups—it stops being “free” in any meaningful moral sense and becomes a tool of harm. The law should draw a firm line at threats, incitement, and targeted harassment, while still allowing tough, even uncomfortable, political and social debate. As someone who’s both an immigrant and a volunteer in a diverse community, I’ve learned that protecting people’s dignity is just as important as protecting their right to speak.

As someone who immigrated from Vietnam and now calls the U.S. home, I value free speech deeply, but I don’t think it should be an excuse for language that directly dehumanizes or incites violence against marginalized groups. Hate speech that clearly targets people based on race, gender, sexuality, religion, or immigration status doesn’t just express an opinion—it creates fear, reinforces inequality, and can escalate into real harm. I believe the law should narrowly limit speech that is explicitly threatening or intended to incite violence, while still allowing room for difficult, even uncomfortable, conversations about identity, culture, and power.

As someone who cares a lot about both my kids’ future and standing up for people with disabilities and other marginalized groups, I think free speech should be strongly protected, but not when it crosses into direct threats, targeted harassment, or incitement to violence. Hate speech that creates a climate where certain groups are afraid to exist openly doesn’t just “express an opinion”; it chips away at their basic safety and dignity. We should still allow tough, even uncomfortable conversations, but draw a firm legal line where speech is clearly intended to harm, intimidate, or dehumanize people based on who they are.

I believe free speech is very important in this country, and even ugly or offensive opinions should usually be allowed, because once the government starts deciding which ideas can’t be spoken, it can easily go too far. But speech that directly threatens people, encourages violence, or clearly tries to provoke attacks against a group should not be protected, because that’s no longer just words, it’s putting people in danger. As a Christian and an immigrant, I think we should be able to argue and disagree strongly, but still treat each other with basic respect and not use our freedom to harm others.

As a lawyer and a staunch defender of the First Amendment, I believe that even repugnant speech is generally protected, because empowering the government to decide what counts as “hate” is a dangerous and easily abused precedent. That said, the law should draw a bright line at direct incitement to violence, credible threats, targeted harassment, and conduct that materially interferes with others’ equal access to public life. In a healthy, liberal democracy, the primary tools against hate speech should be more speech, education, and strong anti-discrimination laws—not broad speech bans that could chill dissenting or unpopular views.

My mamá says that Jesus wants us to be kind with our words, so I think people shouldn’t say really mean things that hurt others because of how they look or where they’re from. I’m little and still learning to talk, but when someone uses words to make people feel scared or bad, I think grown-ups should stop it, like a timeout for hurtful talking.

I think people should be allowed to speak their minds, but hate speech that targets others because of their race, religion, or identity crosses a line. Words can make people feel unsafe and encourage violence, and that’s not real “freedom” for everyone. There should be limits when speech turns into harassment or threats, especially in schools and online, so everyone can feel respected and protected.

I believe free speech is a core American value that helped people like me, an immigrant, find a voice here, and I’m very cautious about the government deciding what we can or can’t say. At the same time, speech that directly threatens or incites violence against others should be clearly restricted and punished. Instead of broad “hate speech” laws that can be abused, we should enforce existing laws against threats and harassment, teach our kids respect at home and church, and answer ugly ideas with better ones.

As someone who’s seen how words can wound as deeply as actions, I believe free speech should be robust, but not absolute when it crosses into direct harm. Hate speech that explicitly incites violence, dehumanizes whole groups, or creates a climate of real fear should be restricted, much like we already do with threats and harassment. We can still protect open debate and dissent while drawing a line at speech that tears at people’s basic dignity and safety. As a Catholic and a liberal, I see it as a moral duty to defend both human dignity and a healthy, respectful public square.

I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, even if it’s unpopular, because free speech is important for learning and debating ideas. But if speech turns into targeted harassment, threats, or words that are clearly meant to stir up violence or serious harm against a group, then it should be limited. That kind of hate doesn’t help anyone and just tears people and communities down.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean, hurtful things about groups of people, because words can make others feel scared or like they don’t belong. At church and at school, we’re taught to be kind, so if someone’s “free speech” is just calling others names or saying they’re bad because of how they look or who they are, I think that should be stopped.

I believe free speech is a core American value and needs to be protected, even when the speech is ugly or offensive. That said, once words cross the line into direct threats, inciting violence, or targeted harassment that puts people in real danger, the law should step in. We shouldn’t be policing feelings or political opinions, but we should draw a hard line at speech that clearly aims to stir people up to harm others.

I think free speech is really important, but I don’t believe it should protect speech that directly targets people with threats, harassment, or calls for violence based on who they are. When hate speech creates a climate where certain groups feel unsafe or dehumanized, it stops being just “an opinion” and starts taking away other people’s freedom to live openly. I’d support laws and school policies that limit speech that clearly crosses into intimidation or incitement, while still allowing people to debate controversial ideas without being censored.

I think people should be able to speak their minds, even if I disagree with them, but when speech turns into clear threats, harassment, or deliberately whipping up hatred against a group, there need to be limits. Free speech shouldn’t mean someone has to live in fear just because of who they are. I’d rather see strong protections for speech, with tough penalties when it crosses into targeted harm or incitement to violence.

Free speech is a core American value, and once we start carving out broad exceptions for “hate speech,” we hand the government the power to decide which opinions are acceptable—and that’s a dangerous road. That said, speech that directly threatens, harasses, or incites violence against specific people or groups should be restricted and punished, because that crosses the line from expression into endangering public safety and order.

I believe free speech is a God-given right and one of the most important freedoms we have in this country, even when people say things I find ugly or offensive. But once speech turns into direct threats, harassment, or calls for violence against a person or group, that crosses a line and should be stopped. As a Black woman and a mom, I know words can hurt, but I’d rather fight bad ideas with better ideas than hand the government too much power to decide what we’re allowed to say.

I think free speech is super important, but hate speech that directly targets people for who they are and makes them feel unsafe shouldn’t be protected the same way. Once speech crosses the line into threats, harassment, or inciting violence, it stops being just “an opinion” and starts hurting real people and communities. We should still allow uncomfortable or unpopular ideas, but there need to be limits when words are used as weapons against already marginalized groups.

I believe free speech is one of our most precious rights, and even hateful words are better exposed to the light than driven underground by the government. That said, speech that directly incites violence or makes credible threats should not be protected, because protecting innocent people from harm is a moral duty. As a Catholic and someone who cares about our community, I think we should use our freedom to speak firmly against hatred, not to silence people, but to answer bad ideas with better ones.

As someone who cares a lot about both civil liberties and equity, I think free speech should be strongly protected, but not treated as an absolute when it crosses into direct harm. There should be clear legal limits on speech that intentionally incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against protected groups, because that kind of “speech” functions more like a tool of oppression than a contribution to open debate. At the same time, we need to be very cautious about how these limits are defined and enforced so they don’t become a backdoor for suppressing uncomfortable or dissenting views.

As a Black Nigerian Catholic woman and an immigrant, I’ve seen how hate speech can create real fear and justify discrimination, so I don’t believe it should be treated as harmless “free expression.” Speech that directly incites violence, dehumanizes whole groups, or creates a hostile environment where people no longer feel safe participating in public life should be limited by law and firmly challenged by society. At the same time, we should protect robust debate, even when it’s uncomfortable, and focus on education and dialogue so we’re not just censoring hate, but actually confronting and transforming it.

As someone who values creativity, diversity, and compassion, I think free speech should be strongly protected, but not when it crosses into direct harm. Hate speech that explicitly incites violence, harassment, or systemic discrimination against a group should face legal limits, because it chills the freedom and safety of the people it targets. From a Buddhist perspective, speech that fuels hatred undermines our shared humanity and makes it harder for communities—including artistic ones—to flourish. We can still allow offensive or unpopular opinions, but draw a firm line at speech that’s meant to dehumanize and endanger others.

As someone who grew up in Mississippi and has seen our country struggle through a lot of hard seasons, I believe strongly in the First Amendment and get nervous when the government starts deciding which words are allowed and which aren’t. Even hateful speech should generally be legal, because once you start policing ideas, you can easily end up silencing religious and conservative viewpoints too. That said, speech that directly incites violence, makes credible threats, or clearly targets people for harm should cross a legal line, because protecting public safety is also a moral responsibility.

I think people should generally be able to speak their minds, even if it’s unpopular or uncomfortable, because open discussion is how we work through real problems. But when speech actively targets groups with threats, harassment, or dehumanizing language that clearly fuels violence or discrimination, there need to be limits and consequences. To me, the line is crossed when words stop being about ideas and start being used as a weapon to intimidate or harm people in their daily lives.

I think people should be able to say what they want, but once it turns into hate speech that targets people for who they are and makes them feel unsafe, there need to be limits. Free speech shouldn’t be a shield for bullying, threats, or encouraging violence, especially against groups that are already treated unfairly.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean things that make others feel scared or hurt just because of how they look or who they are. At school we learn to be kind and not bully, so I think there should be rules so people can’t use words to be super mean or make others feel like they don’t belong.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean things that hurt other people on purpose, especially about what they look like or where they’re from. It makes kids feel scared and sad, and school and the playground should be places where everyone feels safe. You can still say what you think, but if it’s just to be hurtful and make people feel bad about who they are, there should be rules to stop that.

Growing up in Poland and seeing what hateful ideologies can do, I believe words can cause real harm, especially to vulnerable people and communities. Still, in America, free speech is one of our most precious rights, and I’m wary of the government deciding what people are allowed to say. I think truly dangerous speech—like direct threats, calls for violence, or organized harassment—should be limited by law, but offensive or ugly opinions should be answered with more speech, not censorship.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say mean things that hurt others on purpose, especially about how they look or where they come from, because it makes people feel sad and scared. It’s okay to say if you don’t like something, but it should be done in a nice way that doesn’t make anyone feel left out or unsafe.

As someone who grew up in a small Maine town and has spent a lifetime working with all kinds of people in real estate, I think free speech is essential, but it can’t be a shield for deliberate, targeted hate that incites violence or discrimination. We should protect even uncomfortable or offensive opinions, but draw a firm legal line when speech crosses into direct threats, harassment, or organized efforts to dehumanize and endanger specific groups.

I think free speech is a bedrock American value, and the government should be very cautious about policing what people say, even if it’s ugly or offensive. That said, I draw the line at direct threats, incitement to violence, and targeted harassment that clearly endangers others—especially kids and vulnerable groups. From a Catholic and family perspective, we should combat hate speech more through strong communities, moral teaching, and leading by example than through heavy-handed laws.

As someone who works every day to make sure every child feels safe, valued, and included, I believe free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t be a shield for speech that directly incites violence, dehumanizes people, or creates a hostile environment based on their identity. Hate speech that crosses into harassment, threats, or systematic intimidation doesn’t just “express an opinion”; it undermines the dignity and safety of vulnerable groups and silences their voices. I think the law should narrowly target those harmful forms of speech, while still protecting the open, even uncomfortable, discussions we need in a diverse, democratic society.

As a nurse, I see how words can cause real psychological harm and reinforce systems that lead to worse health outcomes for already marginalized groups, so I don’t think “free speech” should be a shield for targeted, dehumanizing hate. I support strong First Amendment protections for offensive or unpopular opinions, but I draw the line at speech that explicitly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against protected groups, especially when it creates a hostile environment in schools, workplaces, or public services.

As someone who cares a lot about fairness and protecting the vulnerable, I think free speech is crucial, but it shouldn’t extend to speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against specific groups. We already accept limits when speech creates a clear danger, and I see targeted hate speech as falling into that category, especially when it creates a climate of fear for minorities. At the same time, we need to be careful that laws don’t become tools to silence uncomfortable but legitimate criticism, so definitions have to be narrow and focused on real harm, not hurt feelings.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say mean or hateful things that make others feel scared or unsafe, especially about their race, where they’re from, or how they look. We can still have free speech to share our opinions and argue about stuff, but once it turns into bullying or encouraging violence, there should be rules and consequences so everyone feels protected.

As someone who cares deeply about personal freedom, I think free speech has to remain broad and robust, even when it makes us uncomfortable. But when speech crosses the line into direct threats, targeted harassment, or incitement to violence against a group, that’s where we need sensible limits, because that kind of “speech” actively undermines others’ freedom and safety. In a healthy, diverse community like the one I volunteer in, we should protect people’s right to speak their minds while also drawing a firm line against speech that’s meant to terrorize or dehumanize others.

As someone who’s seen a lot of history and ugliness in my 77 years, I believe free speech is vital, but it shouldn’t be a shield for directly inciting violence or terrorizing people because of who they are. Hate speech that crosses into threats, targeted harassment, or actively encouraging harm needs legal limits, because that’s where it stops being “just words” and starts destroying people’s safety and dignity. At the same time, I’d rather confront even ugly views with more speech, education, and community dialogue than give the government broad power to police opinions.

As someone who has spent a lifetime studying how environments shape human and ecological wellbeing, I see hate speech as a kind of social toxin: it degrades the civic “ecosystem” and disproportionately harms already vulnerable groups. While I value robust academic and political debate, I believe there must be legal limits where speech explicitly incites violence, dehumanizes entire groups, or systematically intimidates people out of public life. Such constraints are not an affront to freedom, but a necessary condition for a genuinely free and pluralistic democracy in which everyone can safely participate.

I believe free speech is a foundational American right, and we should be very cautious about letting the government decide what counts as “hate” and what doesn’t. That said, speech that directly threatens, incites violence, or harasses people to the point of real harm shouldn’t be protected, because that crosses the line from opinion into abuse. I’d rather see hateful ideas challenged, debated, and answered with better speech and strong community standards than banned outright by law.

As someone who cares deeply about creativity and expression, I think free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t be a shield for targeted hate that dehumanizes people or incites violence. I support strong protections for speech, especially in art and music, but also reasonable legal and social limits on hate speech that directly threatens or endangers marginalized groups. In practice, that means focusing on intent and impact—protecting uncomfortable or controversial ideas, while drawing a firm line at speech that’s used as a weapon to intimidate or harm.

I think people should be able to speak their minds, but hate speech that directly targets and threatens others—especially because of their race, religion, or identity—needs limits, because words can do real harm and make people feel unsafe. Growing up Black and Christian, I’ve seen how constant hateful talk can wear people down and give others permission to treat them badly. Free speech shouldn’t mean you get to dehumanize whole groups without consequences. We can still debate and disagree without turning our words into weapons against each other.

As someone who cherishes the Constitution and believes deeply in individual liberty, I think even hateful speech should generally be protected, because once the government starts deciding which opinions are allowed, everyone’s rights are at risk. That said, my faith and basic decency tell me there must be clear limits when speech directly incites violence, makes credible threats, or is used to organize real harm against others.

As a teacher and a Catholic, I see firsthand how words can either build up a community or tear it apart, especially among kids who are still figuring out who they are. I believe hate speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against protected groups should be restricted, because it doesn’t just express an opinion—it creates a hostile environment that can silence others and undermine their safety and dignity. At the same time, we need to be careful not to label every uncomfortable or controversial idea as “hate,” so that we preserve room for honest debate and learning.

As a teacher and someone who cares deeply about social justice, I believe free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t protect speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against marginalized groups. Hate speech that creates a hostile environment in schools or communities silences others and undermines their ability to participate equally in public life. We should set legal and institutional limits at the point where speech moves from expressing even ugly opinions into actively threatening people’s safety and dignity, while still allowing room for education, dialogue, and growth.
